review_blob: Bottle. Slightly turbid sunny yellow with goopy lacing. Nose of candied lemon, sweet tangerine, earthy oozing stonefruit, grippy texture, pine and honeysuckle. Flavor is grapefruit, papaya, lemon, white flower, soft honey malt, sweet earthiness. Sticky, slick mouthfeel. Medium-plus body. Linger of lemon, green banana and wilting earthy flower with sweetness in the cheeks. Subtly complex and very well-done!

Im never one to turn down a Nelson single-hop. Clear gold pour, modest head, flimsy lacing. Nose is unmistakable, little bit of cereal malt, sweet earthy funk of "gooseberries", herbal and bright Sauvignon blanc, lemon, melon, pineapple, passionfruit. Slightly sweet flavor, candied tangerine, lemon zest, grape must, green floral linger. The more I drink, the more I like. Very nice dimension on the nose.

Bottle. Turbid amber bronze pour with decent retention. Nose is malt heavy with gentle lemon rind and grapefruit rind, pine, flowers. Flavor has some nice young pine, candied lemon, grass, sweet toasted malt. Tasted extremely similar to the FF single hop I had last night. Too much intrusive malt for a hop showcase.

Bottle. Pours murky dense orange with rough sediment, fairly strong lacing. Nose is fairly parfumy, bright young pine, lemon curd, violet and lavendar, overall, floral and bright citrus. Light toasted sweet malt. Flavor is indeed nice and pine-driven, bergamot orange, sweet lemon, white flowers. Caramel and gently toasty malt. Medium-minus body, medium linger of soft pine and orange/lemon peel. Interesting hop showcase, its not bad at all.

Came back to this one, fresher than the last time. Perfectly clear gold, modest head. Nose of pine sap, ripe tangerine, lemon, lime, hint of passionfruit, dried apple, sweet flowers, and lightly caramelized malt. Flavor of bright spruce, white flowers, candied lemon, tangerine, ethereal lavender wafting the roof of the mouth after consecutive sips. Bitter floral finish, clean body, nice hop balance. Unmistakably Alpine.

Been well over a year since Ive had this. Got it in fairly fresh today so I gave it a go. Clear, syrup copper with voluminous head with many different sized bubbles. Nose of ripe apricot nectar, gently toasted malt mingling with young pine, biscuit, and honey. Flavor is deeply juicy and sweet, delicate notes of pine and herb, but overall the malt is a bit too sweet for my liking. Sweetness complicates the linger, but still a nice full-flavored offering. My palate has definitely changed since last year!
beer_name: Avery The Maharaja Imperial India Pale Ale

review_blob: 2016. Pours clear amber gold with substantial head and stucco lacing. Nose is sweet off the bat, a little bit of herbal earthiness riding quietly underneath, over-ripe pineapple and viscous apricot, an ephemeral floral quality. Flavor...resembles my iffy-ness with Hopslam and the added honey sweetness. Its very drinkable, but the beautiful complexity of Mosaic and floral cascade are inevitably dominated by sweet specialty malt. I know that a lot of Clevelanders have had a falling-out with GLBC recently, and this brew was their ultimatum. By all means its a solid and crushable brew. Just a tad heavy-handed on the sweetness for a DIPA. Im not exactly looking for a "brew to guarantee me a headache the next morning" kind of sweetness. But its worth picking up to let you decide for yourself. Cheers!

Brimming gold pour, nice head. Extremely fresh dry-hop nose of resinous green oil, earthy pine, hollow & sugary pineapple and mango, delicate floral notes. Flavor is bright and complex, malleable ripe tropical notes down below, unique earthy Mosaic pine, violet flowers, light minerality, crushable body and easy linger. Very nice. Familiar flavors, but nicely balanced and vibrant. Always love how delicate and detailed Maines brews are (when theyre not TOO delicate and reserved). Liked this one much better than Lunch.

2016. Pitch pour with mocha head. Nose of caramel, vanilla, nuts, milk chocolate, dark roast coffee, bit of char. Flavor is very hot. Burning vanilla and oak, dark chocolate, coffee bitter in the back, medium oiliness. Just...really hot. Alcohol is not hidden, and does hinder enjoyment of other flavors. The ohio batch is definitely still well over 12%. All in all, hype is not a flavor. Ill take any Jackie Os stout over this. Sorry.

Bomber. Near-nuclear bright lemonade haze with modest head. Lemon merengue nose, pale malt, a bit of perfume, piney dry hop. Flavor starts off loose, effervescent and pale, it squeezes its way to a tight, narrowing flowery lemonade. Sticking lemon linger like a yellow-lit runway strip along the entire roof of your mouth and beyond. Super flimsy body, bubbly carbonation. Meh. Not quite feeling this one enough. One dimensional, more of a fruit beer than a pale. Hefty amount of acidity.

Bottle. Deep gold and one-finger head. Nose of broiled broccoli, flavor of broiled broccoli. Is my first Shorts a bad bottle? Tastes like something my mama would make, but unpleasant in beer form. Ill give another bottle a shot sometime.

Bottle dated 3-15. Ive had this brew countless times, but never as fresh as this batch. Gold pour with lovely and healthy head. Nose of clementine, complex Mosaic, tad earthy and piney, super ripe oozing stonefruit way underneath. Flavor starts off bready on the bottom with a delicate juiciness, floral bite, bright and delicious, tad peppery. Words fail me. Amazing and balanced hop spectrum, covering all the bases. Get this one fresh, ladies and gents.
beer_name: Fat Heads Sunshine Daydream Session IPA

review_blob: Bomber into IPA glass. Pours a nice juicy orange with a tight, compact two-finger head. Nose of juicy estery flowers, play doh, bit of pine resin, banana taffy, clove, orange and grapefruit. The yeast also gives it a spicy, herbal, almost rosemary/thyme note. Flavor begins a bit effervescent and brightly bitter, quite resinous pine and floral perfume comes forth, ripe grapefruit juice and pith, nice and non-intrusive yeast presence that gives a slight claylike earthiness as well as a spicy herbal aspect. Not a fan of Belgian IPAs, but this is nice and complex in a lot of lovely ways.
beer_name: Three Floyds Struise Live A Rich Life

review_blob: Can. Pours deep crimson amber with off-white head. Nose of juicy floral rhubarb and blood orange, hop resin, toasted biscuit and caramel sweetness. Flavor is dry, softly bright. Hops are whispy and floral with a bit of bite, translucent-feeling, a tad of resinous molasses. Its good, but the hoppiness is a bit nondeScript and hollow. A red IPA needs a firm and juicy middleground, in my opinion. Still nice and clean!

Bomber from brewpub. Clear straw gold with strong head. Nose of a basic pils; clean malt, slight noble hop, a bit sweet. Flavor is...well a pilsner. A bit grassy/foliage, tad sweet and peppery. Basically tastes like a macro with a bit more body. Glad I only got one.

Growler fill from Hammond location. Near opaque pour with crimson peaking through the edges, wet sand head. Nose of roasted coffee, chocolate and caramel, floral-pine and bergamot orange. Flavor is nice and toasty, firm and bright hop presence of tangerine juice, fresh hop resin, and a sparkling floral bouquet with some pine for good measure. Slight oiliness but a juicy and balanced linger. Very enjoyable and successful offering.

Can. Born yesterday. Clear, bright copper-gold with bubbly thin head. Nose of slightly lime-y, parfumy citrus, biscuity malt, earthy pine & bright floral hops. Flavor starts off like a matte brightness paired with a nicely compromising breadiness. Bittersweet orange rind, tad of flower and pine. Very stiff, tight flavor but it works.

Bottle born on 2-15-16. Sunny gold pour with voluminous head. Nose of prickly mango, lemongrass, young banana, pineapple, pine resin and a steep earthiness. Flavor is bright, resinous, and bitter with grassy lemon, parfumy essences that waft along the top of the palate, pineapple, white flowers, pithy citrus, gently candied fruit, and a crackery malt. Not a show-stopper, but pretty aggressive with nice floral presence. A little too high-noted with nothing below to carry it.

Can. Woody deep amber pour with nicely retaining head. Nose of candied lime, banana taffy, firm toasted yet supple breadiness, young and parfumy floral evergreen. Flavor has a burly body of the dark and bready Munich, more present than the nose, creamy body with bright candied lemon lime notes and banana taffy and pine yet again subtly on the finish. Linger is substantial and relishable. A tad sticky, but an awesome showcase. Bright, sparkly, breezy, all with a solid bottom end. Loved it.
beer_name: Long Trail Smash Project #3 - Munich Malt/Single Hop Equinox

review_blob: Bottle. Sunny yellow pour with light head. Peppery pils/kolsch nose with some cannabis, lemon. Clean pils style malt with a hint more body, lemon and tangerine, flowery, bright and crisp. Not as hoppy as I imagined, and unexpected malt characteristics. Not much of an IPA with the peppery and grainy malt.

Possibly an older bottle. Pours a murky apple cider tone with a substantial and lasting head. Nose of mineral yeast, caramel malt, apricot, honey, and faded hops. Flavor has some gently toasted malt, dried apricot, yellow raisin, rind bitterness. I must admit, imagining it as a fresh bottle, it has a very sturdy malt presence to uphold the hops. Yet in this bottle, it seems so faded. The familiar metallic yeasty nose of an old beer wafts ignonimously from the glass and to your palate. Its a shame I waited so long to try it. Ill give it the benefit of the doubt.

Bottle. Hazed straw gold with teeny head. Light nose of straw, grassy citrus zest, clean minerality, light belgian esters, and young mango. Flavor starts off bright, tart, and salty, moving on to crisp minerality and grassiness, a bit of a mango-lemonhead pucker hugging the sides of your cheeks. Finishes easy with a hint of rock salt and fruity yogurt lingering. Quite good.

Bottle. Pours a hazed, unfiltered sun gold with mild sediment. Fairly compact head clinging lovingly. Nice nose of pineapple, blood orange, and nectarine, contrasted by cannabis, flowery pine, all atop a cereal malt. Flavor starts off bright and juicy with deep tangerine, passionfruit and overripe grapefruit ascending to a floral, pithy, piney finish. All of which sailing along clean, unabrasive light cereal malt. This is a REALLY solid ipa for what its worth. Its got a well rounded hop profile and a crescendo of a flavor experience. Cant tell which I like better between the retro and modern. This one gets an extra .1 for the likelihood of me picking up a 4pack of this.

Can. Pours a pure gold with nice and billowing head. Nose is most definitely old school. Gently toasted grains and barley waft nostalgically with a transparent and simple cascade hop presence with gentle pepperiness. Flavor has a clean and bright bitterness of grapefruit pith and muted hop, with a firm graininess that escorts the minimalist hop notes along the palate. A cool throwback style that was pulled off very well.

Bottle. Dated exactly a month ago. A pour as gold as gold can be, nice head settling to a thick ring encompassing a fairly expansive island of soapy suds. Nose of candied lemon, bright refrigerated red apple, lemongrass, very bright and lively high-noted mango, hints of white flowers, a bit of sourdough bread underneath. Flavor is still fairly fresh. Sprightly candied rind, again a bit of apple (may be a byproduct of two clashing notes), super dry pineapple, passionfruit, and some faintly present herbal/grass elements. Sort of like the Cali Sauvignon Blanc of beers. Malt is dominated by the power of light. Huge brightness overall and medium resin on the finish, sort of like pine without the sparkle but not exactly rindy or pithy. Tropical, intense, gleams as bright as the sun. Would be better enjoyed while digging ones toes in the sand.

Bottle. Super fresh. Rich and deep clear gold pour with tight but relatively small head. Huge blast of a nose. Candied pineapple, mango, papaya, nectarine, grapefruit, tangerine, zested rind, sweet honey, cannabis dankness, touch of pine and a soft floral mirage. Flavor hits hard with a rindy, citrus-heavy start. On the way down, resinous pine, grapefruit, candied lemon and dried pineapple, mango...shit, literally every fruit you could imagine blooms wildly, all with a firm and relishing linger. Pine and alcohol meld together to create a scintillating briskness underneath the massive fruity fireworks show this one puts on. This is a big brew for even bigger hop lovers. Unmistakable, vibrant, clean-drinking slow sipper. Fat Heads knows their way around an IPA. A must-try when fresh.
beer_name: Fat Heads Hop JuJu Imperial IPA

review_blob: Bomber. No born-on date. Murky red-gold pour with tight head. Nose of sweet malt, lemongrass, ripe pineapple washed in oozing nectarine syrup, citrus rind. Flavor is a nice balance of ripe blood orange, lemon, and apricot juiciness, earth and wood undertones, soft rind bitterness, hint of grass, twinge of stale yeastiness, fairly syrupy low-carb body. Slick and smooth. Its a decent offering. Big malt and dense, bottom-end juicy hops.
beer_name: Hoppin Frog Fresh Frog Raw Hop Imperial Pale Ale

review_blob: 2016 black glitter wax. Pours a royal red-amber gold with creamy short-lasting off-white head. Nose of pungent, dripping apricot and maple-y honey, fruitcake glaze, desserts upon desserts wafted by a big booze hotness. Smells a bit like a diabetic hulk-sized alpha king. Flavor presents the same with a refined and easy bitterness, initially a big syrupy body with a triumphantly clean, non-cloying finish. As it warms the alcohol can make your tongue feel like an asphalt parking lot on a July day. Still has that trademark FFF candy hoppiness flavor. This one doesnt disappoint.

Bottle to oversized snifter. Pitch pour with coffee&cream; head. Nose blaring cocoa and espresso, booze, peat, roasted nuttiness, caramel, baking spice barrel notes. Flavor is presented with an immediate yet short note of roasted nuts. Quickly your palate now wades through viscous vanilla and French roast coffee, alcohol hotly dances along your tongue, bittersweet chocolate laps the roof of your mouth, and it all settles mildly in the back of your throat. Durable body with a modest finish. Just enough oil to leave you with a bit of flavor long after a sip. I like this one. The barrel notes dont entirely consume the flavors, and the alcohol doesnt burn like an 11% (although it is still noticeable). I can see why people like this. Stacks up to KBS no doubt.

Bottle. Abyss-black pour with a mild wet-sand head, vigorously poured. Nose of tons of cocoa, high-noted transparent coffee, milk chocolate, green bell pepper (or some sort of nice vegetal contrast) and nuanced hints of floral and rindy cascade and other American hops. Flavor displays much of the same. Heaps of bittersweet chocolate, deeply roasted coffee beans, some "green" foliage, an ominous bitter punch from the hops without an overpowering juiciness. Medium bodied with modest oily espresso linger. Another greatly successful brew from Stone.

Growler filled today from a keg tapped today. Finely-hazed sunny gold pour with small head. Nose of tangerine juice, grapefruit sharpness, candied lemon rind, some flower petals, bread, creamy lychee and a modest helping of pine. Flavor is unripe and rindy, starts off smooth and clean with lemongrass and canned tangerine water, peaks to a high note of muddled floral bitterness, and finishes with a slight candied flavor of the aforementioned notes. The linger is lemongrass and filmy. The hype hasnt won me on this one. Its much more reserved than I expected, and the flavors dont have too great of a depth. There are local breweries here in my own city cranking out IPAs that smoke this one. However I dont intend to dismiss this brew as unworthy. Much like many of Maine Beer Cos works its super clean, very very crushable, and a well-crafted beer. But the hype? Its subjective. All palates are different.

Fresh can. Pours a clear sunny straw with delicate but clingy head. Rindy and crisp tropical nose with cutting bready and grassiness. Flavor is floral, tad grassy, translucent pineapple and mango, light bread. Crushable body. Awesome session.

Bottle. Clear bright gold, lovely head. The nose, in contrast to 80% of the rest of this fruit-infused line, showcases much of the nose of the original with a firm but translucent layer of candied pineapple. Same is said about the flavor. The rindy, balanced juiciness, and gentle pine of sculpin is well-paired with the slightly acidic and candy-like pineapple. This brew, and the Ginger Big Eye were the only ones of the series that didnt taste and smell only like candy and medicine. On draft, this one presents a much cleaner, less residual-sugary element to it. This would be a lovely year-round alongside the grapefruit. Overall, the sweet nose is still a tiny bit artificial.

Bottle to teku. Solid black with active sandy head. Complex nose of grassy lemon rind, a whiff of horse blanket, various acidic and mildly sweet fruits, wilting rose petals, and roasty cocoa just barely rising up from bottom. Flavor boasts some green apple, lemongrass, a little twist of mocha, foliage, rind, mineral earth. Super crushable body, vivid and full-flavored, nicely balanced, and a tad bit funky. This one can be enjoyed ASAP or nicely aged.

Bottle. Pours a perfect clear gold and a fluffy two finger head. Nose of watermelon bubblegum, sort of an artificial element to it, some grassiness. Reminds me vividly of, say, a watermelon flavored toothpaste at the dentist. The artificial watermelon nose is difficult to break through, at least while its still relatively cold. Flavor starts off with that medicinal watermelon syrup, followed by a billowing, bright, dense pine & rind bitterness that is trademark of Dorado. The combination is, well...not pleasing. Im halfway through and this may be a drain pour for me. Very artificial taste. Its abrasive. Gut-twisting, unearthing harsh memories as a toddler trying to choke down Benadryl. Im glad I didnt commit to an entire sixer.
beer_name: Ballast Point Dorado Double IPA - Watermelon

review_blob: Can. Pours a clear bright gold. Solid head. Candy nose radiating pure starburst sweetness, sugar directly mainlined into your nasal passage. Literally. Thats it. Flavor is, again, starbursts with a transparent, clear bottom end. It gives the impression of candy-like sweetness but, in reality, remains fairly dry and clean. To say the least, Ill pick up an original next time. Save a pack for when you have a nice lady around. Too much candy for me.

Bomber. Pours a perfectly clear and gold, healthy white head. Nose of, well, sliced prickly ginger melding with west coast aromatic evergreen, tropical ripeness and gentle malt hide far beneath, only unearthed by a deep, vigorous nasal inhale. Flavor initially heralds a fresh sparkling ginger, midway through it gives in to colorful juicy hops, then a gossamer ginger tingle as it lingers with resinous pine and rind-y hoppiness. This one gets an a-ok in my book. I fucking love ginger. I fucking love IPAs. Nice balance of ingredients, and big eye is a great canvas to showcase the ingredient. Just pick one up, idiot!
beer_name: Ballast Point Big Eye IPA - Ginger

review_blob: Bottle to oversized snifter. Black pour with dark wood softly glowing from edges. Nice head that reduces down to a nice frothy island. Nose is surprisingly doused with American hops. Delicate pine, grapefruit, and bubblegum engulfed in a roasty coffee, wood char, brown sugar, and striking cacao malt. Flavor is has the bitterness of an IPA with subtle grapefruit and citrus notes while gentle, silky, heavy roasted chocolate and cold brew coffee reign over your palate followed by a stiff burn. As it all warms, oh boy...the line between black IPA and imp stout becomes permeable. Drinkable body for an RIS, and finishes bitter but quick. A big beer with a drinkable body and American hops to boot. Quite interesting.
beer_name: Three Floyds Blot Out the Sun

review_blob: 2016 Can. Pours a gently hazed bright orange with an appreciable head, leaning towards the modest size. Syrupy nose like wading through a pure of mango and tangerine, each and every stonefruit, pineapple, some grassiness, and of course a bit of booze. Flavor of some heavy citrus rind, vegetal lemongrass, tropical pure, silky but perpendicular honey texture and sweet grassiness. Easy body and finish for 10%. Bit of a sweet stale grassy linger. I know this is an annual affair and a hot commodity, but...Im not certain why. Its far too syrupy and fruity. Maybe some pine or floral/herbal elements to cut through and balance. Im not trying to seem like "that asshole", but take a step back from the hype and it can become easy to see that youve had some DIPAs much more unique and enjoyable than this. Hate to be that guy, but I guess I have to be that guy for this brew.

Bottle. Red-tinged gold pour with a healthy head, sparse bubbles ascending to the top. Certainly dry-hopped plentifully; first to hit the nose is bright, young spruce, closely followed by pineapple & nectarine, mint, candied citrus rind, definitely displaying the complexity of Mosaic, all atop a gently sweet and peppery malt. Flavor is balanced to my exact liking. This brew allows the caramel, gently toasted malt to set the stage. All the while tons of west-coast pine, bright apple juice, candied citrus, gentle stonefruit meld supremely and colorfully. Refined carbonation and medium, fairly resiny body. Just tasted this after an Alpha King, and I must say, seeing as difference in these brews is almost permeable, I would definitely tip my hat to this one. Piney-ness rules my world.

Murky, o.j. colored body with voluminous head. Nose is tart and rindy, bit of passionfruit, musty basement, gentle clove-y banana esters, fall leaves, gentle anise as it warms; overall a nice balance of herbaceous and fruity notes. Flavor is grassy, tart lemon, worn leather, green apple, spring flower petals and stems, softly puckering, acidity is rounded by ripe fruitiness. Boy oh boy. Very enjoyable.

Pour from tallboy can. Rich clear and deep gold with healthy head. Nose of gentle fruitiness, lemongrass, candied rind, dry dog food malt, bread, mozzarella saltiness? However, flavor is much more admirable. Grainy and smooth malt pair with a rich, juicy, gently lemony yet dry hop-presence. Buttery mouthfeel. No real notable flavors come out. Still, its a juicy, non-bitter, nicely balanced session with a full body for a 4.8%. A bit of residual sugar very present though.

Bottle named "Shilkmake". Pours a hazy, juicy straw gold with a mild but sturdily-clinging head. Nose of wild, mineraly metallic/slate yeast, red berry and kiwi, fierce pineapple. Gently tart strawberry flavor, high-noted young mango, tart lactic acid, sugary breakfast grapefruit, exceptionally zesty and finishes like a tart cherry marscapone dip. Wheat is the most prominent grain and complements the flavors perfectly. Gentle body and a sticking dessert-like fruitiness. A very playful and unique beer. Im enjoying the energy.

Been seeing this same batch in the beer cooler of Whole Foods for nearly a year now. Figured it was time to pick one up. Dense, hazed cola-to-opaque gradient body when illuminated. Hardly any head. Typical bourbon barrel off the bat on the nose; vanilla, caramel toffee, nutty, prickly. A bit of sticky date, a bit of char. Flavor has some great vanilla notes to complement the ripe dried date and sweet chocolate tootsie roll characters. Body is viscous but doesnt stick around too long after a sip. Linger is gently bitter and sugary with some "green" vine-like notes to it. This ones a heavy hitter in terms of ABV. Definitely a bit more than 11.5. Share and enjoy.
beer_name: Jackie Os Bourbon Barrel Brick Kiln

review_blob: 375ml, born on 05.19.15. Active and retaining head atop a lively rich gold. Nose of some grass, belgian yeast, lemongrass, combined notes give a gentle impression of soft baking spice. Flavor definitely resembles gently clove-y belgian yeast, creamy banana esters, some straw and supple citrus rind. Pretty good! Pairs well with an aged Gouda.

Single bottle from Red Wine & Brew. Heavy pour, moderate head quickly dissipating to a few delicate spots. Crystal clear amber-gold. Nose is quite sweet, sugary lemongrass, red apple, quite a bit of bubblegum, quite a bit of candied lemon too. Flavor is a bit more floral but still very candy-like. Bitterness is supported by seemingly nothing, suspended above acidic prickly pine, grapefruit rind and bubblegum with very minimal malt. It does go down easy with a forgiving, crushable body and a bitter linger. But it lacks dimension. Its a single-hop, I know, its not gonna be complex. However the flavors just seem so distant from each other. Seems like an interesting bubblegum/candy/Amarillo-style hop, but for sure needs some support from more ripe and peppery hops. Try a bottle before you pick up a 6-er.
beer_name: Flying Dog Imperial IPA - HBC-291 Single Hop

review_blob: Fresh can. Pours a murky orange-sunset gold with billowing off-white head. Nose is bready with a touch of rye; stick your nose in deep and you get a deep and full bodied ripe pineapple, melony banana, juicy peach. Upon a swirl, rindy lemon-lime, zesty flowers and sharp grapefruit arise as faint spruce sits atop it all. Very fruit-forward flavor blending aforementioned ripe tropical fruit medleys, very refined and refreshing grapefruit and lemon rind, beneath it all a mosaic of sturdy malt flavors, bready, wheaty, peppery rye. Robustly flavorful but finishes mercifully. A bit of chewiness to it for good measure. This one is growing on me the more I drink it. Enjoy, Cleveland!
beer_name: Platform Cherimoya Project - Dry Hopped Kaffir Pale

review_blob: Bottle. Black pour with thin, effervescent and quickly vanishing sand head. Nose is like standing in a busy barista station; wonderful chai spices, fresh prickly green pepper, espresso, vanilla, very festive. Flavor is vibrant and generous with the nutmeg and cinnamon, tad of tingling pepper, some cola, essentially like drinking a cinnamon spice latte. Easy medium-light body, fairly slick mouthfeel, balanced carb. This is very very enjoyable.
beer_name: Chris Banker / Insurgente / Stone Xocoveza Mocha Stout

review_blob: Bottle. Pours amber gold with off white head. Nose of spruce, nectarine, candied lemon, syrupy sugar and breadiness. Flavor is some dense syrupy honeylike malt with an assertive juicy apricot, tangerine and floral hop bite typical of any ASA. Slick, syrupy, smooth & silky mouthfeel. Pretty nice!

22oz bottle from Wine Spot. Im approaching this brew with the knowledge of FFFs dark beer game being much less satisfying than their pale ales. But Ill try to retain neutrality. Poured to oversized snifter, opaque with gentle mahogany shining along the edges, substantial dry-sand colored head that bubbles down to thin and spotty retention and clinging lace. I can smell the plum and dried fruit maltiness from two feet away. Stuck my (slightly stuffy) nose in there, getting notes of brown sugar and vanilla-like oak, noble hop, and a little bit of bubblegum/cola. Flavor starts off bubbly and effervescent, followed by some bittersweet caramel maltiness, finishing with a cola flavor as it goes down. Pretty bubbly. Medium body, medium oily-ness, manageable linger. Im assuming aged on cedar or possibly Oaked. Very subtle but familiar wood flavors and aromas. But hey, I like this. But not exactly running back for another. Definitely worth a pick up if you havent tried.
